text: hey everyone when I was a kid I always
liked these Christmas tree bubble lamp
ornaments and they showed up again in my
life when my dad bought a Wurlitzer
jukebox there at the side of the jukebox
on that model so I thought I'd have a go
at making one myself the bubble lamp
consists of a sealed glass tube with
some methylene chloride inside the tube
and a heat source at the bottom which is
usually a light bulb and the top of the
tube is just out in free air which is
how the heat dissipates from the system
this works because methylene chloride is
a very low boiling point solvent the
boiling points about 40 degrees C so
down here it's actually hot enough for
the solvent to boil and then as the
vapor bubbles travel up the solvent up
here is lower than the boiling point so
the solvent bubble actually dissolves
back into the fluid it's kind of cool
because the bubble doesn't just reach
the surface and then pop it it actually
gets smaller and smaller and kind of
dissolves away before it even hits the
surface I built this by taking apart a
standard squeeze ball pipette and
melting the tip of it shut and I put the
tip in some fiberglass insulation to
keep it from cooling down too quickly I
don't really know what kind of glass
this is but just to avoid you know
cracking and stress as I figured that
I'd cool it down as slowly as possible I
filled the tube up about 3/4 full with
methylene chloride and then sealed the
top up unfortunately glass is a very
poor conductor of heat so I was able to
seal the top without actually boiling
the methylene chloride because that
would make sealing it very difficult
I had to experiment with a couple
different combinations of light bulb and
aluminum foil to get enough heat into
the bottom of this currently this is a
25 watt light bulb tungsten and I've
covered most of it up with foil and to
concentrate the heat on the tube there
these lamps may have gone out of favor
because the methylene chloride is a
fairly nasty solvent as it turns out
most you know low boiling point solvents
are also fairly aggressive so if you
spilled one of these tubes open in your
house it might you know ruin your carpet
or or ruin your floor or give you cancer
or whatever and so you know I can see
why they don't sell these anymore quite
so much too bad they're pretty awesome
lamps okay see you next time bye
